p.s: In the following it is going to be analyzed how the formal and poetic devices thatShakespeare makes use of illustrate and intensify his view on the basis of Sonnet 138.
The sonnet follows a typical Shakespearean sonnet form.
The sonnet is structured in three quatrains with one following heroic couplet.
This intensifies Shakespeare's message in the course of the sonnet, since the header is firstly getting familiar with the content of the sonnet I do believe her, though I know she lies (l. 2).

In the second quatrain the message is expanded On both sides thus is simple truth suppress'd (l. 8) which leaves a shokingshocking impression on the reader, since usually relationships are taughtthaught to be honest.
The third quatrain either sets a turning point or a further explainationexplanation of the message.
In case of Sonnet 138 the Volta is placed in line 9 But wherefore says she not she is unjust.
To the reader this seems as if the narrator feels nostalgic because of the lying of his/her partner and makes the reader therefore sympathetic with the speaker.
In the heroic couplet is the message usallyusually summarised and either expands or explains the thesis of the sonnet, leaving the reader with something to think about.
Furthermore, Shakespearean sonnets usually follow the nene of an iambic pentameter, which is five unstressed and five stressed sylabillssyllables.
This heart-beat like rhythm gives the sonnet life and usually associated with the topics at love, death and time.
In Sonnet 138 the metrestresses the theme of time, which gives the reader an understanding on how the narrator dreads their youth to be over and therefore even lies to their partner.
Shakespearean sonnets are written in three quatrains each paired with a cross rhyme and the following heroic couplet which is written in a part rhyme.
This creates contrasts between all lines and helps the reader to understand the message properly.
Since the heroic couplet is a pair rhyme, the reader understands the intensified theme.
Shakespeare employs poetic devices in order to intensify his message.
The irony used in line 2 I do believe her, though I know she lies stresses the instability and distrust in the relationship.

Paired with the word swears (l. 1) used in the line previously, it creates a contrast, since swearing is usually found in context of marriage and love, additionalyadditionally to low to be truthful in marriage, it leaves a shokingshocking impression on the reader.
This is underlined by the hyperbole [...] made of truth (l. 1).
The person beloved by the persona of the poem stresses to embody truthfulness, when the narrator is aware of their lying.
It makes the reader question their relationship as a whole.

The poetic device used in the following line world's false subtleties (l. 4), which is a contrast to the line before [...] untutor'd youth (l. 3) stresses the age difference between both partners but furthermore reflectreflects the narrator's actual new on his/her partner.
He/Her believesbeliefs his/her partner to be vain and inexperienced while complementing their subleters.
This underlines the sceptical effect on the reader.
The reader starts to further question whether the lyrical I is either in a happy relationship, or if the fault of their untruthfulness is either at the lyrical I's sake or their partner's.
The personification [...] false speaking tongue (l. 7) highlighthighlights the perspective of the narrator on the person beloved.

While it stresses how their partner is not honest, it creates a distance between the act itself and the person beloved, as if the narrator does not want to accept the fact in what kind of relationship they find themselves in.
It creates nostalgia and pityness in the reader because it slowly seems to creep up on the narrator that their relationship is not as great as they claim.
Furthermore this thesis can be stabilized when looking at the use of the word [...] vainly [...] (l. 5).
It underlines their relationship as a whole, an ineffectuat relationship.
The rhetorical question But wherefore says she not she is unjust? (l. 9) underlineunderlines the narrator's desperation.
The speaker wants a stable, honest relationship, while blaming their partner for the lying.
This marks the Volta as well.
AllthoughAlthough it seemed that the lrical I was aware of their dishonesty it still seems to bother them that their partner is not trying to work on that.
This is combined with another rhetorical question and even an anaphor sesyerating each lines by a But [...] (l. 9) and And [...] (l. 10).
The narrator questions [...] wherefore say not I that I am old? (l. 10).
This highlights the narrator's denial and defending of the relationship.
It creates a contract between both lines and dress another fear of the narrator's.
This fear is the fear of aging and transiencetranscience.
The lyrical I fears to lose their partner, and wants to live in dishonesty to uphold their youth.
Up until this point the reader was sceptical of their relationship, when in reality the narrator wants to spend more the with his/her beloved person.
The alliteration [...] love loves [...] (l. 12) shows the narrator's affection for their partner.

It is an antithesis to the line previously [...] love's best havit is in seeming trust (l. 11), since the lyrical I further explains that their relationship does not need honesty to be in a loving relationship.
To the reader this has a positive effect.
Every relationship doffers, but as lanf as both partners are satisfied with the love they share it should not make a difference.
The poetic device used in the heroic couplet [...] in our faults by lies we flatter'd be (l. 14) underlineunderlinesand sui up the message of the sonnet.

The narrator does not expect anyone to understand their relationship, but as long as both partners are happy, untruthful as it is, the lyrical I still can create an illusion of an eternal love that conquers time.
To put it in a nutshell,Shakespeare tries to illustrate the picture of a different, dishonest love, but in whose relationship both partners still seem to be happy.
